none: Northwestern vs. Indiana and Northwestern vs. Purdue

Britten, Benjamin, 1913-1976. Young person's guide to the orchestra

Two performances by the Northwestern University Marching Band during the 1990 season. First, the Northwestern University Marching Band performs at the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Indiana Hoosiers at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Pregame performances include "Indiana Fight," "God Bless America," the National Anthem, and "Go U Northwestern." The halftime show is a tribute to composer Andrew Lloyd Webber and features selections from "Phantom of the Opera" including "Phantom of the Opera," "Think of Me," and "Music of the Night." From "Jesus Christ Superstar," the band performs "What's the Buzz," "Everything's Alright," "This Jesus Must Die," "King Herod's Song," and "Jesus Christ Superstar." The halftime show concludes with "Memory" from "Cats." John P. Paynter conducts the band for "Alma Mater." The second performance is from the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Purdue Boilermakers at Dyche Stadium in Evanston, Illinois. Pregame performances include "Hail Purdue," "God Bless America," the National Anthem, and "Go U Northwestern." The theme of the halftime performance was classical music and included "Symphonic Dance #1," "Candide Overture," and "Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra." John P. Paynter conducts the band in "Alma Mater."

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
